title: Forming Questions
summary: Add ‘lhan’ at the start for yes/no questions. For wh-forms, combine a case marker with ‘lhan’: si-lhan (how), ti-lhan (where), to-lhan (when), ya-lhan (to whom).

title: Noun Classes and Cases
summary: Three noun classes: la- (animate), lo- (inanimate/places), le- (abstract). Cases are prefixes like yu- (accusative), hi- (genitive), mi- (dative), ti- (locative), si- (instrumental), lhu- (purpose), di- (ablative), yi- (comitative), su- (allative). Combine case before class.

examples.english: The person lives in the city.

title: Verbs: Auxiliary + Infinitive
summary: Tovian uses an auxiliary built from aspect root + tense suffix (-e past, -a present, -o future). The main verb stays as an infinitive. Optional mood and voice prefixes attach to the auxiliary.

title: Agreement on Auxiliary
summary: Person is marked on the auxiliary (1st -i, 2nd -o, 3rd -a). Nouns don’t require agreement; plurality is -e for nouns.

title: Attributive Nouns (Adjectives)
summary: Descriptive words are nouns placed after the noun they modify: ‘pelor mot’ = ‘big city’. Order matters; swapping changes meaning.

examples.english: The person lives in the big city.
The big person lives in the city.

title: Introductions via Memory
summary: Culturally, memory and dreams are central. Polite introductions ask how to remember someone, using ‘elom’ (memory) and ‘nalor’ (bind).

examples.tovian: si-lhan wa tlotema nalora ti-le-elom hiwa?
examples.english: How should I bind myself in your memory? (How would you like me to remember you?)
Please bind me in my memory as [Name/Epithet].

title: Dream Motifs
summary: ‘lhen’ = dream. People often share a dream-sign during introductions.
